text: It's Sergio!
Chef Go!
Paras!
I don't remember the moment when I was in told what to do when we were just having a chat there
and with all the drivers and so on.
And I thought it was going to be a normal presentation, right? Normal parade.
And then all of the sudden I get someone shouting at my name and I see him, you know.
He was quite a funny moment.
He was very close to your face.
Paras, yeah, yeah, remember his face pretty well.
Bruce Baffer.
Las Vegas.
It was an awkward moment to watch.
How did you feel at the time?
Yeah, it was pretty cool, obviously.
It's such an icon.
Bruce, that was really, really cool.
And at the time I was just confused, you know, I had no idea where to go, what to do.
And then Luis was looking for a lift because his car was not working.
So he took my car.
So we ended up going on both on my car.
It was quite a funny thing.
It was just a funny, amazing weekend Vegas, wasn't it?
And then of course you go on to finish on the podium.
Was there a good party afterwards?
No, I flew back straight away before Abu Dhabi.
You know, I went home for a few days.
And because then obviously it was a long way.
You know, I was going to spend afterwards like two, three weekends away.
So I wanted to be home for a bit.
But how much time did you get at home?
Because it was such a long flight.
I remember having to go direct to Abu Dhabi.
And I literally left the next day.
I was, I said that home I think today.
I was.
You remember because we were in Saturday.
True, we did get night.
Yeah, we did, yeah.
So Sunday I was back home.
And I spent Sunday Monday.
So it worked really well.
And the last time I saw you actually was at the FIA prize giving in Baku, at the start of December.
Were you there to pick up your P2 trophy?
Where is it?
Where'd you keep it?
At the moment, it's in my room.
Every time we had my room at home, we tried having a brother to, I want to send it back to the office.
But we haven't.
Still, still there at the room.
It's at the risky place, you know, with the kids.
They keep playing with it.
Still alive.
We can't say when you say room.
Do you mean bedroom?
Bedroom.
Bedroom.
Bedroom.
The first thing you see when you wake up in the room.
It's just that when we arrive, we left it there.
And normally we have a place, like a family room.
And where we put all our trophies with my son.
And we put it, we put them all up there.
And it is a reminder.
The new Carlos Reuterman used to keep a helmet at the end of his bed.
So it was the first thing he saw when he woke up in the morning.
And the first thing he thought about was Formula One.
You don't need that inspiration.
No, I don't know.
It was that because of that.
It's more because of it was left there, basically.
And then, so when did you get back to Mexico?
When did the holiday start for you?
Around the 20s of December.
Yeah, because we had the...
We were quite busy after the season with Japan.
We had to go to Honda and the Gala.
And then the team, we had some celebration down in Newtonkins.
So it was really 20s or so of December.
What's the Honda thanks they like at Motegi?
It's great.
It's basically all the Honda drivers get together.
It's a massive event.
And as you can imagine, the physics circuit is pretty much full.
And the energy of the Japanese fans is great.
Did I see a picture of you on a MotoGP bike?
Yeah, did you actually ride it?
No, they didn't let me ride it.
But it was the bike from Mark.
He was explaining me how he does it.
And we do some karting with Daniel, with Jokey, with Max.
So it's a pretty cool event.
So when Mark Mark is telling you how to do it,
I assume he's telling you to get your elbow on the ground.
Yeah, it's pretty impressive what they do, to be honest.
They're brave.
Yeah, I think they're pretty brave.
And so when you do get to switch off, you arrive back in Mexico.
Just tell it, how quickly do you stop thinking about Formula One?
Does it take you a while to wind down?
Or can you just switch off?
It's hard to disconnect because you are always thinking what
went right wrong, what you can improve, how you can be a better driver,
how you can prepare better for next season.
It's always in the back of your mind, although locally,
when I'm home, it can be really far away.
And I have a life out of the sport.
But at the end of the day, this is my life.
And I want to be the best possible I can.
It's difficult to separate, but at times it works well.
And when I'm at home, I'm fully into my family and into my friends.
And yeah, not much Formula One.
What do you do to unwind?
It really comes automatically, obviously, I keep training when I'm at home.
Do you not even have a break from that?
Oh, do you mean on the break?
Yeah, yeah.
Oh, on the break.
I don't train at all.
I try to, but I think I went to the gym once or twice, not much.
I don't actually believe you, because here we're recording this at the preseason test.
And I've seen a lot of drivers come up to you and compliment you on your physique,
saying that you look stronger.
That doesn't happen by doing nothing.
No, I mean, the thing is that we get back to it in January.
So, effectively, you get to 2 maximum, 3 weeks of doing nothing.
It's very hard to lose any form.
You know, you lose some, but we do so much training when the year starts that doesn't change.
Any new hobbies?
Same hobbies.
Golf, karting.
Now I'm more into karting with my son.
We go together to race.
Football, we play a lot of football now together.
And basically, my biggest hobby is to be with my family.
So you've got four kids.
Are we talking about Sergio Jr.?
Yeah, he's the oldest.
And he's the one that you go karting with.
Yeah, I do everything with him now, karting.
We seem to have the same passions, even the...
Even golf.
He likes golf, but he doesn't have time to play at the moment.
Because he's so busy with football and karting that he's really hard to get another sport.
So, tell me about his karting.
Is he quick?
When are we going to see him in Formula One?
What's the... is it just a hobby or is he serious about it?
For now, it's just a hobby.
I mean, it's a six-year-old kid.
He really likes it. He enjoys it.
He's very competitive.
But it's up to him to do it.
I would support him on anything that he wants to do, of course.
But it will be up to him.
All right. We can all learn from our mistakes.
Is there a mistake from your junior Formula career, karting specifically,
that you've learned from, that you can teach him, and he can avoid doing himself?
I think I was really lucky in a way on my karting.
The reason is because I couldn't afford to go to Europe to Italy.
So basically, all my karting was done in Mexico.
But I was always racing guys with a lot of their ages and not myself.
So, that was a good thing.
It kind of complemented in a way, the lack of not being in Europe
with Italian drivers, with all the European drivers.
They have a pretty high level.
I will have loved to drive karting in Europe, but we couldn't afford it.
So, I think there's nothing we did wrong in my karting days with the opportunities
that we have. Obviously, I lack the opportunity to do karting in Italy.
I think that we'll have to help a lot in those early days, but we never had the opportunity.
Right. You're a Formula One driver.
He's going to have more opportunities than you did.
Are we going to see Sergio Jr.? Why the way? Sergio Jr.
Is he Czecho as well?
Czecho as well.
And does he have a Czechinho?
No, just Czecho.
Just Czecho, okay.
But will we see Czecho Jr. racing in Italy, do you think?
Well, if he wants to, at the moment, he's racing mainly at my karting track
with like 10 to 20 other kids.
And yeah, we'll see.
I think he will do some, later on, some races probably in the U.S. in Mexico.
And then we see when we come to Europe, I think he will do some more karting over here.
And if he really wants to do it, then I think once you go into Italy,
he will have to really see if he likes it or not.
And how will you feel if he at the age of 14 goes, I'm leaving home?
I'm going to go and live in Germany, above a restaurant?
I won't be able to speak a word of the language.
Of course, I'm talking about what you did.
And now you're a parent.
Can you see what you put your parents through?
When you did that, it's a massive effort.
The only reason I'm here is because all my family, all together, we gave it all.
And if that's his dream, I think to me, happiness is about pursuing your dreams.
And if that's his dream, I will support him, although it hurts a lot to lose a son that goes so early away.
But it will help him in his character.
Regardless of if he makes it or not into the sport, into the phone one,
it will help him so much.
So I will be really proud for him to pursue his dreams.
And if he does end up on a different continent to you, at least the phone bills are a bit cheaper now.
Because how much did you spend on your home?
What was the worst thing?
I was lucky to be sponsored by Carlos Lim.
You need to ask him.
But it was a lot because even him was complaining at the time.
He must have been a lot like, I remember one, he was like 200,000 pesos.
200,000 pesos, which is like 10,000 euros.
Wow.
You spend a lot of time on the phone.
Not much.
No, but back in the day, it was so expensive.
Yeah, yeah.
It was super expensive to...
Well, wife, I'm cooling us help that, isn't it?
But what about the girls?
I mean, we've got F1 Academy now, is growing and growing?
Do you think they're going to be interested?
I'm pushing my daughter, you know, I really want to get her into cutting.
But she just likes to go and watch her brother, but she's afraid.
And I don't want to push her too much.
So I would love to.
And the younger Olivia, it's still a baby.
But I mean, I will be happy, I think it's just whatever they like to do.
I will just support them as much as I can and try to be with them.
Let's talk about racing genetics.
Because obviously you need no introduction.
Your genes are good for racing.
What about Karole, your wife?
Is she got racing in her family?
No, she doesn't.
She's a driver.
She's a fast driver, she likes to drive fast.
Not so good, but fast.
Is it just me, or does it feel like everyone is either starting a side hustle
or becoming their own boss lately?
And you know what they're hearing a lot of?
That's the sound of another sale on Shopify.
The all-in-one commerce platform to start, run and grow your business.
Whether you're selling fine art or fitnessware,
Shopify simplifies selling online and in-person,
leaving you to focus on everything else without needing to learn any new skills in design or coding.
It's got all of your channels covered from a shopfront-ready POS system
to its all-in-one e-commerce platform.
It even gets you selling across social media marketplaces like Facebook, Instagram and TikTok.
So it's no surprise that Shopify is revolutionising millions of businesses worldwide.
And what I love about Shopify is how empowering it is for entrepreneurs,
giving you complete control over your business and brand,
while quietly supporting you every step of the way
with its award-winning help and extensive business course library.
No matter what your goals are, you'll find it's full of industry-leading tools designed to ignite your growth
and give you the confidence to take your business to the next level.
So what are you waiting for? It's time to get serious about selling
and get Shopify today.
This is Possibility, powered by Shopify.
Sign up for a $1 per month trial period at Shopify.com slash Beyond the Grid, all lower case.
Go to Shopify.com slash Beyond the Grid.
Now to grow your business no matter what stage you're in, Shopify.com slash Beyond the Grid.
Well, let's talk about driving fast on a race track now.
As I said a moment ago, we're at the preseason test.
You've just jumped out of the RB20 for the last time.
Next time you drive it will be in anger in FP1.
What are your first impressions of that car?
Positive. I think we made us the forward.
There's plenty of, you know, when you've done a test in Bahrain.
It's probably one of the hardest track suit tests, you know,
because the track is changing. I'm sure you've seen the graphic.
It goes like two seconds through the day.
So it's just every run so different.
So every change you make, it really has to be based on your feeling regardless of the lap time.
Sometimes you are like, this didn't feel great, but you are half a second faster.
It's like, well, it does feel great, you know, so it's quite difficult to test.
I think we just have to wait and see and positive for the season and looking forward to start.
It looks radically different to last year's car.
How long did it take you to get it dialed in as you wanted it or is it still a work in progress?
No, it did, especially with my program I had. I basically went straight into long run.
And I was like just dialing in, obviously a new car,
feeling how to drive it and so on.
So I think we made some good progress. We've understood quite a lot.
And I mean, we are slowly limited on testing that we did the most we could.
I remember you telling me last year that I can't use the word weakness because it was such a dominant car.
But one of the weaknesses of our B19, if we can call it that, was through the slow speed.
Yep.
Has that been rectified? Is that better this year?
It's better. It is better.
So what kind of feeling are you getting now?
I think that we just improved in all areas. We've done a step forward.
And it's all relatively, you know, I think also the competition has done a step forward.
So it's going to be an interesting championship.
It's so difficult to read testing.
But do you think anyone is a bit closer than they were last year?
Do you think we're going to have a closer fight at the front?
Yeah, definitely. I believe Ferrari are looking good from what I've seen so far.
Mercedes, we haven't seen much of Aston and McLaren at the moment.
And like I said, you know, it's so hard to know that they will be up there.
I mean, I will expect quite a close fight.
And what about the change in direction of this car?
When you first saw the drawing?
Well, when did you first see the drawings for the RB20?
Basically, was when early in January?
Yeah, it was a first reaction.
What was your first reaction?
Well, when you see the drawings, it's hard to pick up.
You know, to notice, I could see that it was a difference, but I thought it was just an evolution.
Rather than when I see it for the first time, it was like, wow, this is a very different concept.
And the ambition of Red Bull Racing is something that I find just so admirable.
It would have been too tempting to just sit on your laurels and say, well, we've got the right concept here.
Let's just evolve what we have.
But no, the team is always wanting to break boundaries.
It's everyone at Red Bull.
Really, the philosophy of the team is just pushing as much as possible regardless of if we are winning.
I think it's only Red Bull who will have just chosen to go that bad.
After having such a dominant year.
It's year four for you in the team.
Just how comfortable are you feeling now?
A lot more comfortable.
A lot better in the team.
Understanding a lot more the Red Bull philosophy of setups and stuff.
I think every year you spend with a team is just better and better.
People forget how long it takes to get fully up to speed with a culture of car, of concept.
All the cars are there are really close.
But how they get the lap time achieved is super different across teams.
You're working with Hu Bird, your race engineer.
Are there Chinese walls in the team?
Is it just you guys on your own, on your car, car number 11, and then there's Max over there and you don't have much to do with him?
Or is there a really good cross pollination of information and ideas?
Just to be a little bit more separate, I think later on, especially as GP moved, you know, Max's race engineer.
It's our chief engineer right now.
So I think everything is coming more together.
Trying to work a lot more closer, both cars, both engineers.
And I think that that has helped the team lately and I think it's something that is going to help through these years, you know, to have that evolution together.
And just being working a lot closer.
How would you describe your relationship with GP?
Well, I know GP was my race engineer back in 2014.
At four-seasons.
So I know him well.
He's one of my friends in the sport, so I know him pretty well.
And does it sit easy with you that he's Max's race engineer as well as the chief engineer?
Yeah, I think it helps the fact that I knew GP from before.
And obviously now his position, he's not just Max's race engineer, he's also a chief engineer.
So it helps you not to have that dialogue between us.
So Checo, you've touched on, you spend a bit of the winter reflecting on what's just happened in 2023.
What is a good year for you in 2024?
Where is the bar for you this year?
It's just maximizing every single opportunity.
It's at 24 races calendar.
And just being able to raise one, hit it the track, raise by race, you know, and have that evolution.
And just maximizing the opportunities because I know if I'm able to do that, I will have a great year.
And two maximizing opportunities.
Is it all about qualifying?
I mean, is it a lazy assumption just to look at the qualifying results from last year?
Checo must be struggling in qualifying or do you think there were reasons for it?
Yeah, there were reasons for it.
Obviously, it's not like I forget to drive from one weekend to the other.
There were reasons behind it, we understood them.
And I think we are in a better, you know, better shape.
So how do you set about maximizing your opportunities?
Let's start on a Saturday.
I think basically just being able to focus on the right approach for the entire weekend.
Getting quality done properly, making that progression.
I think what happened last year was that we lacked a lot of progression through the weekend.
And I think being able to dial in, improving from Friday to Saturday, Saturday to Sunday,
making those jumps through the weekend will be key.
Because we always started strong, but we sort of stayed there.
So it's just important having that evolution and working together with the team.
And working together with the simulator as well, you're not trying to have a good base back there in Miltonkins.
Right. So I know you say for our rear close, but the assumption in the paddock is that you guys are going to be the people to beat.
Which means you've got to beat your teammate, obviously.
What makes Verstappen so hard to beat?
I think that he's really at one with the car.
With the team, he's at the moment of his life, he's in top form.
And he comes to a weekend and he knows exactly what he needs to go fast and keeps improving, keeps making it faster.
Those who make mistakes often, I think he's just very tough to beat.
We will try and give it a go.
As we started really close, very closely match.
And this year we'll see how we start and how we are within the first few races.
How important is it to get off on the right?
Very important.
You know, these first few races are super important because it really puts you on a pair to use teammates.
So these first few races are very important.
Because as you say, those first four, certainly four races last year, you were right there.
And when you're analyzing 2023, what conclusions did you reach as to why it slipped away?
Because you were on the money to begin with?
Yeah, I felt like the car was just as it started to evolve.
He just went out of me.
Even on the simulator, I will jump in and within a lap, I will be not focusing so much on getting the lap time.
It was more about developing the car.
But as the car developed, I will jump in the same and I will be chasing the lap time.
It wasn't coming so naturally as it was coming early in the season.
So you start to make compromises, to make you feel comfortable.
And in that window of making me feel more comfortable, I think we made the car slow and on our side.
And it's something we understood.
Compromises in terms of setup.
So you're chasing it the whole time.
Yeah.
Before you even get, you know, you're talking about the momentum that you build up over a weekend.
There were moments last year when you would arrive at a track chasing it before you even turned away.
Yeah, very much.
And how difficult was that for you?
It was difficult, you know, because especially as you're having such a dominant teammate that is winning all the time.
But you are not able to extract the maximum out of the car.
You know, and it's not an easy situation, but the thing is, when you have to be mentally strong, focused on yourself.
And make sure that you are, you give your best and be able to deliver when you can.
Old-top sportsmen use psychologists as far as I can make out, certainly in Formula One.
You did last year.
How did that help you?
I think it helps to understand perspective from the outside, you know, because sometimes we get dragged into it so much
that at times it's good to have someone that understands the sport, that knows what's going on, and can be from the outside.
Just having that conversation and just making you realize that, oh, probably this is wrong or this is right.
Having a different perspective from someone from the outside, I think it's always helpful.
So that person that you go and see, they're not giving you advice on how to drive a racing car clearly.
So how was it somehow loosening up your brain and how you drive the car? What was being said?
No, basically, I mean, one thing is that mentally you have to be strong and making sure that you're focused on the red stuff, you know, because in Formula One, there are so many distractors.
There are distractors around and people that are experts all around the world and they know exactly what's going on.
But you are inside and you have no clue.
So just making sure you're focused on your job, it's a monkey.
Don't let any noise or any of the outside noise influencing any of your decisions. I think that's okay.
We're all used to seeing the drivers turn up to the races, kidded out in their best outfits, each with their own unique style.
But there's one thing all great clothing has in common for you to look and feel your best and that's a well tailored item that fits your shape perfectly.
And that's why I'm delighted to have been introduced to Indochino. It can be so hard to find good fitting items that still feel comfortable.
But Indochino makes fully customized clothing that doesn't require a trip to the tailor to get that perfect fit.
You can measure yourself at home using their step-by-step guide to create your personalized profile or just visit a showroom where they do it for you and get a custom suit starting at just $399.
I used Indochino's online service to try it out and size myself up for one of their blue, haily cotton stretch shirts.

And let me tell you, it was so easy to place an order. I've never done anything like this before, but the website walks you through every single measurement you need, which only takes about 10 minutes.
And when it comes to customization, they've thought about everything from the length you need to the buttons, the collar and the pockets.
And you can choose whether you want your cuffs angled or a classic French cuff. You're really getting that tailored experience with Indochino without the luxury price tag.
And all those little details you might not normally consider really do make for a stylish personalized statement.

I can't wait to try my shirt when it arrives and it will, of course, make an appearance in the FIA drivers press conference or on one of the upcoming Beyond the Grids, which can be watched on F1's YouTube channel this season.
So level up your game with Indochino. Got Indochino.com and use the code grid to get 10% off any purchase of $399 or more.
That's 10% off at Indochino, I and Dio, CHINO.com with the code grid.
Hi, beyond the grid listeners, it's Laurence Bruto here. So we've had a first look at the upgraded cars for 2024. And we could very well see a fight on our hands this season.
With F1 TV Pro, you can experience every angle live. That means live streaming and riding on board. Plus join me and the team for its exclusive weekend shows.
The best part, you can watch how you want anytime, anywhere on any device.
Get F1 TV Pro from Unmissable 2024 season. Sign up now for your 7-day free trial.
F1 TV Pro is only available in select territories and TCCs apply. So check out the website for more details.
You've been in F1 since 2011. Can we talk about the outside noise? How much more noise is there now than there was 257 races ago when you start?
There's always pressure in phone, no one. You have to remember that we are at the pineapple of the sport.
So there's always pressure. You always have to deliver at all conditions, at all races. That's normal. But at Red Bull, it certainly has changed a bit.
There's a recent way that lots of drivers have been survived because the amount of pressure, the amount of focus on yourself,
they don't measure the same all the teams. I feel like how they measure Red Bull is different to anyone else.
And how has social media ramped up the noise that we're talking about?
Because when he started, there was no, there was no, there you're right. I think quite a lot.
I think I'm privileged because I'm maybe all there and I grew up without social media. Yeah, it can be really toxic.
So I'm not a big fan of that. So I always try to stay away from it and making sure that I'm able to come here to my job, give my everything prepared as best as I can.
That's all I can do. I can try 1000 times at the end of the day. The most important is to do with your team, try to deliver.
The outside noise will always be there. There's nothing you can do about it, but it's important to make sure that you are able to shut it down.
And how much noise is coming out of Mexico?
Well, a lot. The expectations back home, it's big. The support I get is pretty big. It's just great. I think I'm being a Latin American driver, in full one.
It's a big thing because that comes with a lot of people behind. I'm very privileged to have such a support from home.
And I can only say that it's a great privilege to have.
Tell us a little bit more about your fame in Mexico, because I think when we go there, you are literally staring at us from every billboard.
Is it true that you even had a burner phone, a mobile phone, the race last year, just have a different phone, just cut the noise back.
Is that true? Yeah, it's true. It's a very intense weekend. The energy from Mexico.
It's a big thing. Probably for the European drivers, there are a lot more use to have everyone drivers here and there every now and then.
But for my country, for Latin America, it's something like, you don't get a lot. It's a big thing back home because it just sounds crazy.
Having a Mexican in Formula One, it's quite a big thing. I mean, in our history, we've only had five or six drivers in this sport.
It's really hard to make it into the sport, but to have a successful career in Formula One, it's another level.
What would it mean to you to do the biz at the Mexican Grand Prix? You finished on the podium, but that win. What would it?
I'm looking at you now on the podium, on the middle step. I think there would be tears.
Well, I don't know how you will react to it, but it will be a big dream for me. You know, to be able to win at home in front of my home crowd will mean a lot.
Do you dream about that? It's a dream. Yeah, definitely a dream. A big one. I've won great races, historic races, but I think one that I'm missing is winning at home.

So funny one, isn't it? Jensen Button never won the British Grand Prix. And he always says, oh, I'll give up so many of the other races just to have won at Silverstone. Do you feel the same way about makes you?
Yeah, it is because winning at home and you're something a lot more special than anything else.
And how do you manage the expectation? Because as you say, you're mobbed everywhere you go, 90% of the people at the race track are there to see one man.
Does that give you energy? How do you just keep a lid on things and make sure that you drive as you know you can drive a knot and not let it spill over?
It's again the same as the whole season, you know. But it's different. It's Mexico, it's Czecho and Mexico.
Yeah, but at the same time it's a championship. There are 24 races out there. When Mexico finishes off, it gives them the same amount of points.
If there is a race that you want to do even better, it's obviously your home. But the best way to do it is by focusing on track, focusing on the right self.
Because it's so easy to get distracted from it and get carried away from it.
But how do you stay focused? I'm fascinated about you. It's interesting your entourage, the people that you take with you to the races.
It's very similar to the one that you had back in the day. Louis has been with you since the early days. Is it savvy? Your trainer still comes to you?
How important is it for you to just have those old friends, old faces around? Does it help keep you grounded? Does it help keep you focused?
Yeah, but also having the contact with your race team, making sure that I always take them for dinner when we are in Mexico.
Because I like to remember myself and them that we hit for Formula One and that Formula One experience, above anything else.
That is the main thing for us. What restaurant?
We always changing the restaurants. But the last three or four years we have always done a team dinner in Mexico with you.
Just max turn up, or is it just your side of the garage? Sometimes, no, the whole team. I invite the whole team. And Max has been to a couple of them.
Cool. Just while we're on the topic of Mexico.
I don't know how into music you are, but I've been told that you've featured in two music videos in the last 12 months.
One with bad bunny.
Yeah.
There's no disrespect to bad, but I haven't heard of bad bunny. My kids might have done. I don't know. Just tell me about bad bunny and the making of the vid.
Yeah. He was back in Monaco. And he was there and some bits were recorded and went into his song, I think, which is called Monaco.
Yeah, I mean bad bunny is huge in Latin America. Yeah, it's a phenomenon back in America.
And there's even a, is there a song about you that has also been quite successful?
There have been a few, a few songs in the past. How does that feel? You've got songs being written about you, Jacko.
Are they love songs? No, no, they're not love songs. There's another one from Carine León as well that is also a very famous Mexican singer.
And there's another one or two more that they've done about me.
Can you sing?
I'm really bad singer.
I don't want to hurt the audience. Just a line now? No, no, I don't want to hurt them.
I've heard a few at coming on maybe with Shalla Clare. You know Shalla's just released a new album, right?
Yeah, yeah, yeah. I asked him earlier, where he is in the charts and he refused to tell me.
Come on, we all know you guys are so competitive. He's probably there every morning looking to see where he is on the charts.
I'm sure he's looking at it. It's got to be number one.
So the songs about you, aren't there curries about you? There's a curry house in Oxford.
Curry house? Curry is not about me. He's just in the menu. It's one of my friends.
What is it? What is it? Is it a...
It's called Chaco Pérez Fiesta, which is a dish. It's a menu.
What is it? It's a curry of a little bit more spicy curry. Yes.
Quite tasty, actually. Yeah. It's near Silverstone. It's a curry place that I've been going since I was in Formula 3 days.
Oh, okay. Yes. It's like going home. Yes, it's pretty much.
It's next to Silverstone. Embroidery. Okay.
Now, a little bit more about your preparations.
I mentioned earlier, 257 races. You're not the new kid on the block anymore.
But have you done anything different in your preparations this year?
What do you tweak it? Fernando Alonzo, for example, has changed his diet.
He says he's going to deal with the jet lag differently this year.
I'm not sure how he's going to do that. But are you going to do anything differently?
Yeah. Firstly, physically, I try to put more training in place in place for the start of the season.
Because then later on, it's all about maintaining. So, trying to get a little bit more time in it has been beneficial.
I feel comfortable in the car. And yeah, the other things just trying to minimize the travelling that we end up doing.
You know, planning better, the simulator days, the days that I go back to Europe or back to Mexico,
we're trying to reduce the travelling. It's quite important because when you think about it, it's 24 races.
Planning also the schedule for sponsors. For all the sponsors we have in the team.
But all the days we have, it's quite a thing now, the planning of your schedule.
Right now we are all fresh and smiley. But when we go halfway through the season and still there is another 15 races to go,
it's important to keep the energy level high.
How are your physical numbers? Are you fitter now than you've been prior to any season in Formula One?
You say you're trying to up it?
Yeah, I think it's always very hard. Obviously you have these numbers that you based on quite a bit on them.
But there are a lot of other things. You know, you have a restrained during the year. It's a lot harder to measure.
I feel good. I felt really good yesterday. I jumped in the car and I started away. I was doing a race in the car.
So I feel good. It's a little bit painful always. The shoulders are hurting because of the seat position, not being used.
The neck is just getting used to those places of your body, but it's just part of it.
Is your seat position in the car the same as last year? Is it the same every year?
Yeah, but you are always making adjustments with new cars.
Hides going up, going down, always trying to figure it out where you put it.
Do you sit a little higher in the car for the street races?
Something Mika Hickenon used to do. He used to sit a little bit higher.
I'm just sitting with these tires. The spikes that we have on top of the tire makes it really hard to see.
So you see us sitting a lot higher.
For the street races?
Everywhere.
Okay, but you don't just change it specifically for the...
No, no, no.
I just try to put...
If you were able to see an enormous circuit, you should be able to see on a straight circuit.
Okay. I think that's it.
So you're sitting higher in the car now than you were 10 years ago?
Yeah, I remember back then it was more important to be low.
I remember like always a good driver.
When the lowest and able to...
What, center of gravity? Get it down, get it down.
It was quite a big thing back in the day.
But you know, one has evolved a lot and you see drivers going up and down and it doesn't really matter.
And does someone like Adrian Neue get involved in your seat position?
Does he say, Checo, you're too high, it's affecting this and that.
More than that is just like, you need to be high.
So what we do about it, you know, how...
How are they...
Does that change?
Because it has an impact, you know, on...
Engine temperature, on flow and stuff like that.
So it's quite a big thing.

Now a lot of people listening to this will think of you as a street circuit specialist.
All right, you've won Monaco, you've won Baku.
I remember Andrew Green when he was technical director of force India telling me that
your right foot has traction control in it.
Is it, are you a hypersensitive?
Is that hypersensitive?
Not that I'm aware of, but it has been obviously one of my strengths throughout my career.
The race, rough, and...
But a real limited track seems to suit you, is that fair?
So, how do you then go about transferring those skills onto front limited tracks?
It's all about adapting.
Formula 1, it's all about that.
You're not trying to be flexible with driving, how you approach a corner,
hit and then, and always try to make the maximum out of every single race weekend
because when race, the limitation is real, the next one is a front.
You know, always trying to figure it out, it's important.
So, Checa, I'm getting loads of positive vibes out of you.
I know you've only done a day and a half in the car, and in fact the schedule here was changed a bit, wasn't it?
Yeah.
Because of the schedule, because of the drainage problem that we had.
But I'm getting positive vibes.
So, if you and I were to sit down at the end of this season,
and you're reflecting on the year just gone,
what is a good 2024 for you?
I did what I performed at my best within myself.
I really made a step as a driver in all races throughout the year.
That would be a good year for me, just making sure that I keep progressing,
that I keep getting better, year by year, and that will obviously be translated to the results.
And last year was a bit up and down, can we say?
Yeah.
When was the last time you sat down and was having that conversation with yourself in December,
where you felt that you did get the maximum out of yourself?
When was the last time where you went, that was a good season.
I've had good seasons, definitely.
I think one of them,
it's a lot how you are able to get the maximum out of the car out of you.
I think the year before,
what was 22?
True, yeah, 22.
22 was a better season.
I think I grew up a lot, and that's why I started the year so strongly,
because it was such a good year.
It was a year that I really developed, and I was coming up together with Red Bull.
That's why at the beginning of the year, I was on a part to Max.
But as things evolve, we got a little bit more difficult,
so it's something we're going to make sure that doesn't happen.
Okay, and there is going to be a lot of, we're back to the noise thing,
the background noise, but with Lewis going to Ferrari in 2025,
it has sort of opened up the driver market massively.
There's going to be a lot of talk about you, obviously.
Do you enjoy that musical chairs?
And in Julian Jacoby, your manager, do you feel you've got the right men calling the shots
or helping you call the shots?
Yeah, definitely.
I think it's just, we've been working together for a long time.
I do my job, and I let him do his job.
It's as simple as that.
If I, if I deliver on track, it would be easy for him.
And for me, it's all about results.
So after 14 years, you get less bothered about it.
It's not like when you are a lot younger,
you are a lot more concerned of Formula One.
You think Formula One is too big when you come here,
and then you realize that as well.
It's just a sport.
And has the senior management at Red Bull giving you a target?
Is there a, is it a number of wins that they won't need to achieve?
Or is it just, is it less specific than that?
They would just, no, they deserve and see how you're.
They just want, they just want me to perform.
They know what I can do.
They just want me to perform at my best.
And if I'm able to do that, they, for sure, they will want me to stay.
Okay.
Daniel Riccardo said that when he took some time out at the start of last year,
one of the things he wanted to do was to fall back in love with Formula One.
Remember why he fell in love with racing all those years ago?
And he says it's really helped him just sort of get a different perspective on it,
a more sort of excitement in a way.
Do you feel the same way?
Do you feel you need to re-engage with that check-over from 20 years ago?
No, I feel like I'm really, I'm a good, positive way,
how I see the sport, how I deliver the maximum out of myself.
How I get the maximum out of myself, I think it's really important,
you know, how to, how you approach to do race weekends and your life.
So I'm pretty happy in general the way I see, I see, I feel the sport,
you know, I have a vision of it and I'm happy the way I sit.
And can you remember the Eureka moment when you first fell in love with Formula One?
Well, it was when we started karting very much in, when we were four, four, five years old.
It's when that was the first time that I was like, well, I hope one day I can be there.
And whatever happens this year, Eureka is going to love Formula One forever.
Yeah, definitely, you know, it's been my life for many years,
not just a year that I've driven in Formula One since before, you know,
it has given me everything.
It's been, yeah, I think I will always be grateful to Formula One
and it's been a massive pleasure to be part of it, you know,
I think every single people that come here and see how this sports operate,
it's a great thing, you know, and it's just great to be part of it.
Many more years to go though.
Yeah, yeah, not that many, but they are good years ahead.
Until you become a racing dad with Sergio Juni, you need to always race.
We race, yeah, exactly.
I don't want to say it never, but you never know what the future holds, you know.
Once you retire, you really want to go, I feel like the day I retire,
I really want to go disappear for a few years, you know, and do something different.
But you never know if I have to be here.
Chaco, it's been brilliant to have you on the board.
Thank you very much for your time.
Before you go, we've got a new thing this year.
I'll quick fire questions, okay?
And I've got five.
What else are you good at, number one?
Good question.
I'm lucky to be a racing driver, I'll say.
No, no, I'm good at...
What are you good at?
What are you interviewing?
Luckily I'm asking the question.
It's a good question.
Goal?
No, I haven't really discussed goal.
You're obsessed with it.
I'm a good striker, football striker.
Are you better at football than golf?
Yes.
You seem convinced by that.
Yeah, I'm not that good at golf.
I don't have the time.
Football comes more naturally.
Second question.
Which racing driver would you want to be stuck in a lift with?
A life or...
Let's do both.
Well, obviously Arton Senna, you know,
we love to meet him.
I think he was a great guy.
I feel like we have a lot in common.
How we see this sport and how we lift our lives as well.
So, obviously, the Latin blood is just something we will have
understand each other a lot.
A life...
Good question.
I mean, I see all these drivers every single weekend,
so I wouldn't like to get stuck with none of them.
I think more from my previous teammates, you know,
with Koyashi, with Jensen.
I think those were great teammates and great guys to hang up with.
Question three.
Who would play you in a film?
Tom Cruise.
Of course he would, right?
Right.
Question four.
Who is the coolest person in your address book?
I'm not really that much into fame,
so I would say more of a normal people,
just my friends, you know, I think who's your coolest friend?
What do you mean with Kool?
Just bad bunny.
I have good friends, you know,
that I think when you have those friends where you can just call them
and have a laugh about a good day or a bad day,
and just make like half fun and laugh about anything.
You have a good click.
I digress, there is one more question.
But do you have any genuine friends on that grid?
Or is the intensity of the rivalry too strong?
I think we have a lot of respect for each other.
I think we've all gone through a lot to be here.
But we all here for ourselves,
and we all want to be the best of ourselves.
I think once you finish the sport,
you become great friends because you've been sharing this for so many years.
That automatically, it doesn't matter if we don't see each other ever again in our lives.
We know that one day when we see 20, 30 years from now,
we will remember with pride, you know, a name.
And it's something that's hard to explain,
but I'm sure what I'm telling what I'm talking about.
A lot of drivers get it, you know, because...
People have been on the same journey.
Exactly.
We've been on the same journey for so long,
and it's just right now,
we all focus on our careers so much.
And it's the same to us in the world.
You know, we have very different persons to...
to our normal people, you know,
because we live so much on this sport,
and this sport takes so much out of us,
that it's really hard just to...
to be normal in that regard.
So once we're finished with this, I feel like everything feels more...
or feels more natural.
Yeah. Right, final one.
If you hosted a podcast, who would be your first guest?
Well, I have to go big, so I will invite Cristiano Ronaldo.
Right? Have you met him?
Yeah, yeah, yeah, I met him.
I think we'll be...
No, just people that...
that have done great things with their lives,
that have good impact to society.
I think it's important these days
to look at people that are...
are not just successful,
that are good for us,
are good examples to look up.
How was Cristiano Ronaldo?
Did you tell him what a great striker you were?
No, I didn't.
He's friends with one of my friends,
so he's...
yeah, Gregay, remember I met him a few years ago in...
well, many years ago in Madrid.
Yeah, he's a good guy.
Alright.
Check out. It's always a joy speaking to you.
Thank you very much for your time.
Best of luck in 2024.
